page.title: 15AINTREE RACECOURSE HISTORY
page.content: The originator of the{Grand National was William Lynn, an innkeeper and owner of the Waterloo Hotel Liverpool. He advertised for a race to be run on February 29th 1836 "A sweepstake of 10 sovereigns each, with 80 sovereigns added for horses. Winner to be sold for 200 sovereigns if demanded". In 1857, Lynn secured the support of Liverpool Corporation who contributed 100 sovereigns towards the stake money. From only 4 starters in 1837 (just 2 completed the course), the number of starters steadily increased and in 1971 the number of starters was 38. Only 13 finished showing what a challenge the{Grand National}is. The race was nationalised in 1945 and five years later "wizard" Topham leased the course from Lord Sefton.
